text: those who lived through the storm said
it felt like the world was going to end
a cyclone Pam slammed into Vanuatu
leaving utter devastation it brought
with it a ferocity rarely seen in the
South Pacific the capital Port Villa has
been torn apart storm surges several
metres high have battered the coast
while houses and livelihoods have been
lost there are fears that some isolated
communities could have suffered terrible
losses at least eight people have been
confirmed dead and another 20 injured
but the authorities warn that those grim
numbers could well increase on a trip to
Japan the President of Vanuatu has
appealed to a United Nations Disaster
conference for emergency aid I'm
speaking with you today with a heart
that is so heavy I stand to appeal on
behalf of the garment and people of one
order to the global community to give a
lending hand the category 5 system the
most severe had been expected to skirt
Vanuatu but shifted course leaving
populated areas directly in its path
charities fear cyclone Pam could be one
of the worst natural disasters the
region has ever endured I've been in
port dealer township so this morning we
had to go on foot because the roads were
blocked by trees and debris and fallen
power lines and everything else and it
really looks like a bombs gone off in
the town centre there's there's you know
shutters scattered everywhere there's
there's corrugated tin roofs everywhere
you'll see an harbour just littered with
funking yachts and boats the cyclone has
already caused widespread damage in
other parts of the South Pacific
it is moving south and the authorities
in New Zealand are preparing for the
storm which is forecast to pass north of
the country in the next two days Phil
Mercer BBC News Sydney
